p: Staphylococcus aureus, a Gram-positive coccal bacterium belonging to the Staphylococcaceae family, frequently colonizes the nasopharynx, respiratory tract and skin [ 92]. It is both a commensal bacterium and a human pathogen, with colonization rates of approximately 30% in the general population, although higher rates are observed in young children and the elderly [ 92, 93]. S. aureus is also a leading cause of bacteremia and infective endocarditis as well as osteoarticular, skin and soft tissue, pleuropulmonary, and device-related infections [ 93].
